content:
EDIT

* Added variables for [[tweet]]

* Added constants for [[c]] && [[covfefe]]

* Reword grammar a bit

* Added test case whereby the last word that starts with C is not the longest one (as mentioned by @StepBack13 below)

* Changed to Python 3 and modified solution to be compatible

Nice challenge, but could use at least one more test/validator pair.

I just got this in a clash and misread the puzzle as "replace the LAST word starting with c with covfefe", and I got 100% on the test cases, so I submitted. Ended up with 75% on validators.

It would be good to add a test case where the longest c word isn't also the last one, so that others can't make such a mistake. :)
Great theme. My comment is only that tweets should be <= 140 characters.

I love the theme :D

I think you can make it a bit more challenging than just checking first character and length of words. 
What about checking some patterns in the words which would match 2 consecutive letters in covfefe? 

At the end of the day, this is your puzzle, so you do what you want ;)

Hey,

I had an idea for a testcase while solving this: you could have two c-words with same length, with one of them also having a coma or something at the end to make it seem longer if the string split is done without caution. For example:

[...] commonly, [...] clearest [...]

Here "commonly," might seem one character longer than "clearest" because of the coma, but they actually have the same length and it is then the later word that should be replaced.


Funny challenge that you’ve come up with there! ;)
Wouldn’t it be too hard for a CoC?
I've replaced the word "convert" with "change" in Goal section.
damn, it's CoC, I'm an idiot. Sorry :)
I also think it's a bit difficult for a Clash of Code, but for a Community Challenge, it's fine :)
